data.title: Syntax error in JSON for Azure IoT Edge "Push module images"
data.body:
## Note  
Issues in this repo are for tracking bugs, feature requests and questions for the tasks in this repo 

For a list:  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

If you have an issue or request for the Azure Pipelines service, use developer community instead:  

https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/spaces/21/index.html )

## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: AzureIoTEdgeV2

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises? Azure Pipelines
    
    - If using TFS on-premises, provide the version: 
    
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: 


- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name:

    - If using private agent, provide the OS of the machine running the agent and the agent version: 

## Issue Description

When trying to setup the "Push module images" action of the task, the `azureContainerRegistry` parameter needs to be specified as a valid JSON object. This is undocumented and leads to a very hard to debug error in the log, where the only failure is:

```##[error]SyntaxError: Unexpected token a in JSON at position 0```

After finding issue #13261 this helped me to find the root cause.

### Task logs

Can be provided on request but this is the relevant snippet, redacted:

```
2020-08-18T10:05:06.2062925Z Pushing module images...
2020-08-18T10:05:06.2065233Z ##[debug]containerregistrytype=Azure Container Registry
2020-08-18T10:05:06.2077212Z ##[debug]containerregistrytype=Azure Container Registry
2020-08-18T10:05:06.2078416Z ##[debug]azureSubscriptionEndpoint=<subscription_guid>
2020-08-18T10:05:06.2079480Z ##[debug]azureContainerRegistry=aregistryname.azurecr.io
2020-08-18T10:05:06.2100083Z ##[debug]task result: Failed
2020-08-18T10:05:06.2136264Z ##[error]SyntaxError: Unexpected token a in JSON at position 0
```

Note that the "unexpected token" is "a" which matches the first character of the name of the azureContainerRegistry.

## Troubleshooting
Checkout how to troubleshoot failures and collect debug logs: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/vsts/build-release/actions/troubleshooting

### Error logs

See Task logs above.

## Suggested fixes

After figuring out where the problem actually was, setting the `azureContainerRegistry` parameter correctly was done like this:

```
azureContainerRegistry: '{"loginServer":"$(azureContainerRegistry)", "id":"/subscriptions/<subscription_name>"}'
```

Please at least fix the documentation so that this is apparent. The current version at

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/build/azure-iot-edge?view=azure-devops#container-registry-types

strongly suggests that only the DNS name is enough.

Next up I don't see why this needs to be a JSON object including once again the subscription, seeing as that is specified as a separate parameter. Would be better to accept the DNS name in my opinion.

data.title: JSON substitution is case sensitive by default, and also does not log missed keys that match apart from case
data.body:
This is somewhat similar to the issue below, but my point is more of a difference in design opinion than a bug:
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/6656

Relevant code to the best of my knowledge, or in the general vicinity:
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/a6f349070b6ed807a134974af44e49cf262b8037/Tasks/Common/webdeployment-common-v2/jsonvariablesubstitutionutility.ts#L71

Comment from 6656 that I have found to be true:
'JSON variable substitutions are case-sensitive. Ensure that the casing provided in the variable and appsettings.json are same.'

First, I disagree with this decision as a default.  I can't think of many, if any, cases where I would want to differentiate two json elements by case within the same level.  True, JSON _is_ case sensitive and it does allow for two keys to be differentiated at the same level based on case.  But is this really something a user would ever intend to do?  Perhaps, but probably not.  Which thus leads me to my next point.

If case sensitive vars are unlikely to be intentional, the default should be case insensitive with case sensitive as an override option.  However, this is a breaking change and so on.  If we don't agree here, a log statement would help quite a bit to mitigate this.  "The following pattern was matched, but JSON variable substitution is case sensitive.  Skipping this key."

One could arguably blame the user for making the case mistake, but I would offer the counterpoint that good UX / DX design should strive to match intent of the user and warn them when there may be a mismatch between intent and results.

Thanks,
Travis

data.title: ExtractFiles incorrectly finds archives recursively

labels.name: awaiting deployment
labels.description: Related changes are waiting for deployment to be completed

data.body:
## Required Information

*Type*: Bug

*Task Name*: ExtractFiles


## Environment

*Server*: Azure Pipelines
- Account name: wencorepo
- Team project name: Dependencies
- Build number: 34933
- Pipeline: libzmq (definitionId=20)

From log:
- Agent name: 'Azure Pipelines 2'
- Agent machine name: 'fv-az246'
- Current agent version: '2.173.0'
- Operating System: Ubuntu 18.04.4 LTS
- Virtual Environment: ubuntu-18.04 20200806.0
- Agent running as: 'vsts'


## Issue Description

The ExtractFiles task incorrectly extracts an archive (.tar.xz) that is nested under a subdirectory, even though we did not use a globstar (**) pattern in archiveFilePatterns.

It looks like `minimatch.match()` (extractfilestask.ts ln 87) is incorrectly matching files in subdirectories.
```js
var matched = minimatch.match(allFiles, parseResult.search, matchOptions);
```

This behavior occurs regardless of whether archiveFilePatterns is `'*.tar.xz'` or `'$(Build.SourcesDirectory)/*.tar.xz'`. It is a 100% repro.

I think it must be something about the minimatch version or its usage within Azure. I cannot reproduce the issue with a standalone copy of latest minimatch from npm.

Task definition:
```yaml
  - task: ExtractFiles@1
    displayName: Extract dependencies
    inputs:
      archiveFilePatterns: '$(Build.SourcesDirectory)/*.tar.xz'
      destinationFolder: '$(Build.SourcesDirectory)'
      cleanDestinationFolder: false
```

Pipeline details:
- Run: #20200812.4
- Job: Linux_owa4x
- Task: 'Extract dependencies'


### Task logs

Full debug log: [ExtractFiles-debug-log.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/5082526/ExtractFiles-debug-log.zip)


### Error logs

This part of the log illustrates the issue. Notice there is no globstar (**) but it still finds recursively:

```text
##[debug]using: 1 archiveFilePatterns: /home/vsts/work/1/s/*.tar.xz to search for archives.
##[debug]searching for archives, pattern[0]: /home/vsts/work/1/s/*.tar.xz
##[debug]normalizedPattern= /home/vsts/work/1/s/*.tar.xz
##[debug]parsePattern: /home/vsts/work/1/s/*.tar.xz
##[debug]makeAbsolute:/home/vsts/work/1/s/
Searching for: *.tar.xz under directory: /home/vsts/work/1/s/
##[debug]findPath: '/home/vsts/work/1/s/'
...
##[debug]11981 results
##[debug]Candidates found for match: 11981
##[debug]adding file: /home/vsts/work/1/s/depends/owasys_owa4x/gcc-linaro-5.3-2016.02-x86_64_arm-linux-gnueabihf.tar.xz
##[debug]adding file: /home/vsts/work/1/s/libsodium-1.0.18-linux-owa4x.tar.xz
Found: 2 files to extract:
/home/vsts/work/1/s/depends/owasys_owa4x/gcc-linaro-5.3-2016.02-x86_64_arm-linux-gnueabihf.tar.xz
/home/vsts/work/1/s/libsodium-1.0.18-linux-owa4x.tar.xz
```

See also full log: [ExtractFiles-debug-log.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/5082526/ExtractFiles-debug-log.zip)

data.title: Azure Functions Misconfigures Slot on Deployment
data.body:
**Type**: Bug
**Task**: Azure Functions
**Environment**: Azure Pipelines
**Agent**: Hosted, version 2.173.0

## Issue Description

The slot being deployed to is using runtime version 3.0.14120.0 on Linux on EP1. It's not using Docker at all.

When deploying to a slot, the task updates _App Service Configuration settings_ with `{"linuxFxVersion":"DOCKER|microsoft/azure-functions-node8:2.0","appCommandLine":""}`. This completely breaks our app, which then can't run after a deployment.

The task also updates _App Service Application settings_, and while there's no reason to do so it at least doesn't break anything.

I've tried using `az functionapp deployment source config-zip` through the Azure CLI task, but I can't get that to work either.

### Task logs

```
2020-08-14T13:59:40.7699277Z ##[section]Starting: Deploy
2020-08-14T13:59:40.7712138Z ==============================================================================
2020-08-14T13:59:40.7712582Z Task         : Azure Functions

data.title: docker@2 push: bad performance when pushing images
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: docker@2 push: bad performance when pushing images

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
TFS on-premise - Azure DevOps Server Version Dev17.M153.5


- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
  
private
agent version: 2.164.8
OS: linux x64

## Issue Description

When I use the Docker@2 task to push docker images, it seems like it always pushs all layers, even thoguh the layers already exist in the registry.

I compared the Docker@2task with a manual call to "docker push" using a bash task. The bash task detected that all layers already exist on the server and completed in less than 1 second. The Docker@2 push task ran 52 seconds.

```yaml
  - bash: |
        docker login -u $(USER) -p $(PASSWORD) $(DOCKER_REGISTRY)
        docker push $(DOCKER_REGISTRY)/$(repository):$(version)-$(hash)
    displayName: Push docker image (app) - without Azrue DevOps task

  - task: Docker@2
    displayName: Push docker image (app)
    condition: and(succeeded(), eq(variables['publish'], true))
    inputs:
      containerRegistry: Harbor
      repository: library/$(repository)
      command: push
      tags: |
        $(version)-$(hash)
```

data.title: CacheV2: Unable to find pipeline caching scopes.
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug (essentially a reopen of #11869)

**Enter Task Name**: CacheV2

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Hosted
    - ubuntu-latest and Ubuntu16, agent version 2.173.0

## Issue Description
Same as #11869: when using the Cache task, I get the error "Unable to find pipeline caching scopes." (see logs below).

The pipeline is a pure YAML multi-stage pipeline. The problematic stage looks like this:

```yaml
stages:
  - stage: deploy_app
    displayName: Deploy app
    condition: and(succeeded(), or(eq(variables['Build.SourceBranch'], 'refs/heads/master'), eq(variables['DEPLOY'], 'true')))
    jobs:
      - deployment:
        displayName: Deploy
        environment: ${{ parameters.environment }}
        variables:
          - template: /infrastructure/azure-pipelines/state-secrets-variables.yaml
        strategy:
          runOnce:
            deploy:
              steps:
                - checkout: self
                - download: current
                  artifact: drop
[...]
                - task: Bash@3
                  displayName: Set npm_config_cache
                  inputs:
                    targetType: 'inline'
                    script: |
                      echo "##vso[task.setvariable variable=npm_config_cache]$(Pipeline.Workspace)/.npm"
                - task: Cache@2
                  displayName: Restore npm cache
                  inputs:
                    key: 'v2 | npm | "$(Agent.OS)" | infrastructure/package-lock.json'
                    path: '$(npm_config_cache)'
                    cacheHitVar: 'PULUMI_NODE_CACHE_RESTORED'
                  condition: and(succeeded(), ne(variables.PULUMI_NODE_CACHE_RESTORED, 'true'))
[...]
```

This issue first appeared after switching the `job` to a `deployment` job and adding an `environment`. 

While the Cache task is nested in a template multiple levels below, it does not fail on all pipelines that use the template. The directory structure is roughly as follows:
* /
  * ts-apps/
    * [...]/pipeline.yaml (these all work fine)
  * python-apps/
    * [...]/pipeline.yaml (these don't)
  * infrastructure/
    * azure-pipelines/
      * [...]
      * pulumi-command.yaml (this is the template that contains the Cache task and it's being used in all other pipelines)

data.title: Bad symlinks are not allowed in the cache directory
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: bug

**Enter Task Name**: Cache@2

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines

You can see it here for example: https://dev.azure.com/tinygo/tinygo/_build/results?buildId=1954&view=logs&j=ca395085-040a-526b-2ce8-bdc85f692774&t=bcb59787-fffd-4f14-b766-2e58e1ea8247


- Agent - Hosted

## Issue Description

Full output:

```
tarting: Cache LLVM source
==============================================================================
Task         : Cache
Description  : Cache files between runs
Version      : 2.0.1
Author       : Microsoft Corporation
Help         : https://aka.ms/pipeline-caching-docs
==============================================================================
Resolving key:
 - llvm-source-10-windows-v1 [string]
Resolved to: llvm-source-10-windows-v1
ApplicationInsightsTelemetrySender will correlate events with X-TFS-Session 3787af5f-e83c-4ee1-8085-ae7570df197d
Getting a pipeline cache artifact with one of the following fingerprints:
Fingerprint: `llvm-source-10-windows-v1`
There is a cache miss.
tar: ./libcxx/test/std/input.output/filesystems/Inputs/static_test_env/bad_symlink: File removed before we read it
ApplicationInsightsTelemetrySender correlated 1 events with X-TFS-Session 3787af5f-e83c-4ee1-8085-ae7570df197d
##[error]Process returned non-zero exit code: 1
Finishing: Cache LLVM source
```

The error is this line:

```
tar: ./libcxx/test/std/input.output/filesystems/Inputs/static_test_env/bad_symlink: File removed before we read it
```

I believe this matches [this StackOverflow entry](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56216397/file-removed-before-we-read-it). It appears that Cache@2 uses the `-h` flag to tar, which then chokes on an (intentionally) bad symlink. You can see the symlink here: https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/blob/release/10.x/libcxx/test/std/input.output/filesystems/Inputs/static_test_env/bad_symlink

### Task logs

[Enable debug logging and please provide the zip file containing all the logs for a speedy resolution]

## Troubleshooting
Checkout how to troubleshoot failures and collect debug logs: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/vsts/build-release/actions/troubleshooting

### Error logs

[Insert error from the logs here for a quick overview]

data.title: AzurePowerShell@5 does not log the command line anymore
data.body:
## Environment
Azure Devops
- Agent - Hosted windows-2019
    
## Issue Description

With AzurePowerShell@4 the command line of the "script file path" executed was logged . Also all parameters and their values were logged after the script command.


With AzurePowerShell@5 nothing is logged at all.
This make our task very difficult to understand wich command failed and for what parameters.
I have no time to add this kind of logs in all of my scripts.
Can you please set the command line back in the logs.
Maybe you can add a parameter to enable the command line logs if you think this is more appropriate.

data.title: Azure IoT Edge V2 - Deployment is not fetched by device
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: AzureIoTEdgeV2

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    Azure pipelines

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    Hosted agent

## Issue Description

I'm not sure, whether this is a bug in the pipeline task or one in the IoT Hub. But I don't know where to report bugs in IoT Hub, so I'm reporting it here.
When the action `Deploy to IoT Edge devices` is executed, everything seems to be ok. Any existing deployment is overridden on the IoT Hub. But sometimes randomly the deployment is not assigned to the matching devices. In the device the _IoT Edge Runtime Response_ is **417 -- The device's deployment configuration is not set** and in the tab _Deployments_ there is no deployment assigned any more.

I figured out two workarounds which both involve manual actions:

- Delete the deployment on the IoT Hub before releasing a new one
- Edit the deployment (do dummy changes) and save it

In both cases the deployment get fetched by device.

- Agent - Private: 
    - Version 2.153.1 on Windows Server 2016 Standard 10.0.14393

## Issue Description

When attempting to use the GitHub Release task in Azure DevOps on premise installation with on-premise GitHub Enterprise I get the following error

`The pipeline is not valid. Job Job: Step GitHubRelease input gitHubConnection expects a service connection of type github but the provided service connection GitHub Enterprise is of type githubenterprise`

Request the functionality please be added to the task.

data.title: JavaToolInstaller needs support for Service Connection certificate authentication
data.body:
The JavaToolInstaller task only supports a service connection with service principal key and not a certificate when retrieving the binaries from an Azure Storage blob container. 

Please consider adding this feature as for our organization and I imagine many other we have a requirement to harden the service principal authentication to only allow certificate authentication.  

## Issue Description
To reproduce this error create an Azure Resource Manager service connection with certificate authentication and one JavaToolInstaller task which retrieves the binaries from an Azure Storage location:

```
- task: JavaToolInstaller@0
  displayName: 'install java 11 from azure storage'
  inputs:
    versionSpec: '11'
    jdkArchitectureOption: 'x64'
    jdkSourceOption: AzureStorage
    azureResourceManagerEndpoint: ***
    azureStorageAccountName: ***
    azureContainerName: tools
    azureCommonVirtualFile: 'zulu11.37.17-ca-jdk11.0.6-linux_x64.tar.gz'
    jdkDestinationDirectory: '$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/jdk11'
    cleanDestinationDirectory: false

```
The error statement in the pipeline log is as follows (service principal id redacted): 
##[debug]Processed: ##vso[task.issue type=error;]Endpoint auth data not present: ***

The Azure Resource Group and the Packer Build tasks were fixed with this pull request: [11994](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/pull/11994). 

The same logic is missing form the following source file: [AzureStorageArtifactDownloader.ts](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/master/Tasks/JavaToolInstallerV0/AzureStorageArtifacts/AzureStorageArtifactDownloader.ts)

### Error logs

```
...
Retrieving the JDK from Azure blob storage.
##[debug]azureCommonVirtualFile=zulu11.37.17-ca-jdk11.0.6-linux_x64.tar.gz
##[debug]azureResourceManagerEndpoint=***
##[debug]azureStorageAccountName=***
##[debug]azureContainerName=tools
Downloading artifacts from Azure blob storage, Container Name: tools
##[debug]Getting storage account details for devtesttools
##[debug]6978987a-86e5-4b46-a31f-d487f4b231a5 data subscriptionId = ***
##[debug]6978987a-86e5-4b46-a31f-d487f4b231a5 auth param serviceprincipalid = ***
##[error]Endpoint auth data not present: ***
##[debug]Processed: ##vso[task.issue type=error;]Endpoint auth data not present: ***
##[debug]task result: Failed
##[error]Endpoint auth data not present: ***
...

```

data.title: TRX file cannot be correctly located in VsTest 16.7 in Azure DevOps Pipeline
data.body:
## Description
Starting today, the VsTest 16.7.0 is available in Azure DevOps pipeline. We got an error message at the end of the VsTest step that it clamied TRX was not found when publishing the test. 
It appears the VsTest was looking for trx file in ```\agent\_work\_temp\TestResults``` while it was actually saved to ```$(Common.TestResultsDirectory)```

We were using VsTest 16.6.1 with the same pipeline this past Sunday without problem.

## Script
Here is the part of our yml pipeline file:
```yml

- task: VisualStudioTestPlatformInstaller@1
  displayName: 'VsTest Platform Installer'
  inputs:
    versionSelector: latestStable

# To avoid vstest execution error, we need to split tests into group by framework version.
- task: VSTest@2
  displayName: 'VsTest - testAssemblies - .Net Framework'
  inputs:
    testSelector: 'testAssemblies'
    testAssemblyVer2: |
      **\MyApp.UnitTest.dll
      !**\obj\**
    searchFolder: '$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)'
    vsTestVersion: 'toolsInstaller'
    codeCoverageEnabled: true
    pathtoCustomTestAdapters: '$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/test/UnitTests/MyApp.UnitTest'
    otherConsoleOptions: '/ResultsDirectory:$(Common.TestResultsDirectory)'
```

## Environment
The agent is running at Windows 10 1803

data.title: IIS Web App Manage (On machine group) | Adding bindings should be a graceful operation
data.body:
**WHEN** choosing the "Add binding" option in a "IIS web app manage" task
**IF** you have a binding that requires a certificate (https) and you have a thumbprint provided
**THEN** the first initial deployment will succeed
**THEN** all the consecutive ones will fail on the part where netsh is called in a similar manner:
`"netsh" http add sslcert ipport=0.0.0.0:443 certhash=*** appid={a78bae04-5ec5-4fc4-a879-c9fd8ba3ddb0} certstorename=MY`
**BECAUSE** the binding with the given certificate already exists

So currently you have to no if you are deploying a binding initially or not, and customize the deployment and only turn on/enable the add bindings part for the initial one or else it will fail.

I think it would be proper if given the error message _SSL Certificate add failed, Error: 183
Cannot create a file when that file already exists._ we shouldn't fail the task, and continue adding missing bindings if any or with execution of next task, but currently this fails a deployment.

data.title: AzureCLI Variable escaping
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Arguably both

**Enter Task Name**: AzureCLIV1, AzureCLIV2 

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines (Releases, classic)
   
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: 
UNIUN, UNIUN, Uniun Website, releaseId=1071&environmentId=2584


- Agent - **Hosted**:
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name: **win-latest**

## Issue Description

When using the AzureCLIV1 or V2 task in a classic Release pipeline,
If using variables in the "inline script"
The variables aren't escaped according to the scripting environment being used.
See: https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/13161 for more detail.

This means, suppose you want to use a variable in the inline script, and it has been entered into devops and it may contain a special character (special as deemed by the scripting language used by the task, e.g batch script, powershell etc) - you have to create a second copy of that variable in devops, that is the "escaped" version of the same variable, and use that version in the inline script of this task. Otherwise the script will break.

This means you have to maintain two copies of such variables, and manually keep them in sync. This is not ideal. Is there a better way to solve this?

Perhaps you could add a "Escape variables?" option to the task, so that when this is checked, any variables uses in the inline script, will be escaped based on the rules of the target scripting language?

### Task logs

[Enable debug logging and please provide the zip file containing all the logs for a speedy resolution]
See: https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/13161 for more detail.

## Troubleshooting
Checkout how to troubleshoot failures and collect debug logs: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/vsts/build-release/actions/troubleshooting

### Error logs
See: https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/13161 for more detail.

data.title: Code coverage is showing as 0% in SonarQube when using the Jacoco option in the MavenV3 task.

labels.name: awaiting deployment
labels.description: Related changes are waiting for deployment to be completed

data.body:
## Note  
Issues in this repo are for tracking bugs, feature requests and questions for the tasks in this repo 

For a list:  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

If you have an issue or request for the Azure Pipelines service, use developer community instead:  

https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/spaces/21/index.html )

## Required Information

**Bug**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: MavenV3

MavenV3:  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises? Azure Pipelines
    
   - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: 
Org:  MetLife-US
Project Name:  Dental
Build Definition Name:  DMA-PFR3-Release
Build Number:  1.37441


- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
    - Private, RedHat 7 OS, Agent version - 2.165.0

## Issue Description

It seems that the MavenV3 task was recently updated from version 3.171.0 to version 3.173.0.  After the update we can see that the code coverage is showing as 0% in SonarQube when using the Jacoco code coverage option in the task within Azure DevOps.  We can see in the commit history for the MavenV3 task that there were some updates for the code coverage report path and we are wondering if that is the source of the issue.  If we switch to the Cobertura option the code coverage appears properly in Sonar.  

### Task logs

[Enable debug logging and please provide the zip file containing all the logs for a speedy resolution]

## Troubleshooting
To Troubleshoot the issue we tried installing the newest SonarQube plugins, specifically SonarJava and Jacoco.

### Error logs

There is no error in the logs, but the code coverage appears as 0%, where as previously it was approximately 50%.
